text: The <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein is expressed on the surface of all B-lymphoid cells with the exception of terminally differentiated plasma cells and has been implicated as a signal-transducing receptor in the control of proliferation and differentiation .

Here we demonstrate complete correlation between the expression pattern of the <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene and the B-cell - specific transcription factor <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in a large panel of B-lymphoid cell lines .

The human <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene has been cloned , and several <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding sites have been mapped by in vitro protein - DNA binding studies .

In particular , a high - affinity <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding site instead of a TATA sequence is located in the -30 promoter region upstream of a cluster of heterogeneous transcription start sites .

Moreover , this site is occupied by <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in vivo in a <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - expressing B-cell line but not in plasma or HeLa cells .

This high - affinity site has been conserved in the promoters of both human and mouse <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes and was furthermore shown to confer B-cell specificity to a <extra_id_0> beta-globin reporter <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in transient transfection experiments .

In addition , <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found to be the only abundant DNA - binding activity of B-cell nuclear extracts that interacts with the <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
